message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Skeletal survey is the standard diagnostic evaluation for suspected child abuse and should be performed as soon as possible. Babygram and bedside ultrasonography are not reliable imaging techniques for detecting fractures, and MRI may not be readily available in an emergency setting.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Skeletal survey is the gold standard for imaging in cases of suspected child abuse, as it can detect multiple fractures in various stages of healing. A babygram is an X-ray of the entire baby, but it may not show all fractures. Ultrasonography and MRI are not commonly used in evaluating fractures.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The most preferred imaging technique for suspected child abuse is a skeletal survey, which can detect multiple fractures in different stages of healing. Babygram is less sensitive and may not detect all fractures. Bedside ultrasonography and magnetic resonance imaging are not typically used for skeletal imaging. Waiting for 2 weeks for a repeat skeletal survey is not recommended as early intervention is crucial in cases of child abuse.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Skeletal survey is the standard imaging technique for suspected child abuse and should be performed within 2 weeks of the initial presentation. Babygram and bedside ultrasonography are not recommended as standard imaging techniques. Magnetic resonance imaging may be useful but is not the most preferred imaging technique in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Skeletal survey is the initial imaging modality of choice for evaluation of suspected abuse in infants due to its ability to detect healing fractures. Babygram and bedside ultrasonography have limited diagnostic value and magnetic resonance imaging is not the preferred initial imaging modality for evaluating suspected fractures in infants.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. In cases of suspected child abuse, a full skeletal survey is recommended as the first line of investigation. This allows for identification of any other fractures or injuries that may not be evident on physical examination or initial imaging. Babygram and bedside ultrasonography are not sufficient for a comprehensive evaluation of bone fractures. Magnetic resonance imaging may be a useful adjunct to identify soft tissue injuries, but it is not the first choice for evaluating bone fractures.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A skeletal survey is the most preferred imaging technique for the evaluation of possible child abuse in infants. This can detect radiographic evidence of fractures and can be used for follow-up evaluations. Babygram is not specific enough for detecting fractures, bedside ultrasonography may not reveal all the fractures and is not a standard diagnostic test for child abuse. Magnetic resonance imaging is not the initial imaging modality for evaluation of possible child abuse.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Skeletal survey is the most preferred imaging technique for suspected child abuse cases. Babygram and bedside ultrasonography are not sensitive enough to detect all fractures, while MRI may be helpful but is not as widely available as skeletal survey.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A skeletal survey is the most preferred imaging technique for suspected child abuse as it can show multiple fractures in different stages of healing. A babygram may not show subtle fractures and bedside ultrasonography and magnetic resonance imaging may not be as effective in detecting fractures. Waiting for 2 weeks to perform a skeletal survey is not appropriate as it delays the necessary evaluation and treatment for the infant.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A skeletal survey is the most preferred imaging technique in suspected cases of child abuse. A babygram is not as comprehensive, bedside ultrasonography may not show bone abnormalities, and magnetic resonance imaging may not be readily available and may not be as useful for detecting fractures. Waiting for 2 weeks for a follow-up skeletal survey is not appropriate in cases of suspected child abuse, as it delays necessary intervention.
